content: For the synthesis of CoSe using MOF-derived Co3O4, a NaHSe solution (as a selenium source) was obtained by heating 50 mL of a 0.2 M NaOH solution containing 0.04 g of Se powder and 0.6 g of rongalite at 80 °C until all Se powder was converted to selenide. After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.
clean_text: For the synthesis of CoSe using MOF-derived Co3O4, a NaHSe solution (as a selenium source) was obtained by heating 50 mL of a 0.2 M NaOH solution containing 0.04 g of Se powder and 0.6 g of rongalite at 80 °C until all Se powder was converted to selenide. After cooling to room temperature, the Co3O4 template deposited on the FTO substrate was dipped into the NaHSe solution to fabricate the CoSe film. The SEM images in A,B revealed that the dodecahedral morphology of ZIF-derived Co3O4 was well-retained in CoSe after anion exchange. EDX analyses of the film showed CoSe with an atomic mass ratio of 1:1 (Figure S7A). Also, EDX elemental maps showed that Co and Se elements were uniformly distributed in the CoSe nanostructure (Figure S7B,C). The HR-TEM image in  revealed a well-defined crystalline structure with lattice fringes of 0.20 and 0.31 nm, corresponding to the values of the (102) and (100) planes of CoSe planes, respectively.
